Line 1: Line 1: −

{{subcat guideline|notability guideline|Geographic features|WP:NGEO}}
 
{{nutshell
 
{{nutshell
 
| A geographical area, location, place or other object is presumed to be notable if it has received significant coverage in [[Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources|reliable sources]] that are, in the case of artificial features, [[WP:SECONDARY|independent of the bodies which have a vested interest in them]].
 
| A geographical area, location, place or other object is presumed to be notable if it has received significant coverage in [[Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources|reliable sources]] that are, in the case of artificial features, [[WP:SECONDARY|independent of the bodies which have a vested interest in them]].

Line 29: Line 29:  
* '''Populated, legally recognized places''' are typically presumed to be notable, even if their population is very low. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can be notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. One exception is that [[census tract]]s are usually not considered notable.
 
* '''Populated, legally recognized places''' are typically presumed to be notable, even if their population is very low. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can be notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. One exception is that [[census tract]]s are usually not considered notable.
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the GNG. Examples may include subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, informal regions of a state, unofficial neighborhoods, etc. – any of which could be considered notable on a case-by-case basis, given non-trivial coverage in multiple, independent reliable sources. If a Wikipedia article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the informal place should be included in the more general article on the legally recognized populated place or administrative subdivision that contains it.
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the GNG. Examples may include subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, informal regions of a state, unofficial neighborhoods, etc. – any of which could be considered notable on a case-by-case basis, given non-trivial coverage in multiple, independent reliable sources. If a Wikipedia article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the informal place should be included in the more general article on the legally recognized populated place or administrative subdivision that contains it.
−
* '''Disputed regions''' are generally considered case-by-case. Their notability for Wikipedia is independent of the validity of their claims. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
+
* '''Disputed regions''' are generally considered case-by-case. Their notability for Wikipedia is independent of the validity of their claims. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles into ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
 
* '''Named natural features''' are often notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands, etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is enough verifiable content for an encyclopedic article. If a Wikipedia article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature can instead be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, a river island with no information available except name and location should probably be described in an article on the river.
 
* '''Named natural features''' are often notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands, etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is enough verifiable content for an encyclopedic article. If a Wikipedia article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature can instead be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, a river island with no information available except name and location should probably be described in an article on the river.

Line 7: Line 7:  
{{Notability guide}}
 
{{Notability guide}}
    −
[[Wikipedia:Notability|Notability]] on Wikipedia is an inclusion criterion based on the encyclopedic suitability of an article topic. Per Wikipedia's [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|Five pillars]], the encyclopedia also has features of a [[gazetteer]]; therefore, geographical features meeting Wikipedia's [[WP:GNG|General notability guideline]] (GNG) are ''presumed'', but not guaranteed, to be notable. Therefore, the notability of some [[geographical feature]]s ([[Location (geography)|places]], roadways, objects, etc.) may be called into question.
+
[[Wikipedia:Notability|Notability]] on Wikipedia is an inclusion criterion based on the encyclopedic suitability of an article topic. Per Wikipedia's [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|Five pillars]], the encyclopedia also functions as a [[gazetteer]]; therefore, geographical features meeting Wikipedia's [[WP:GNG|General notability guideline]] (GNG) are ''presumed'', but not guaranteed, to be notable. Therefore, the notability of some [[geographical feature]]s ([[Location (geography)|places]], roadways, objects, etc.) may be called into question.
     
This guideline summarizes the existing overall consensus for geographical feature notability and provides guidance on inclusion of information about geographic features into Wikipedia.
 
This guideline summarizes the existing overall consensus for geographical feature notability and provides guidance on inclusion of information about geographic features into Wikipedia.

Line 19: Line 19:      
==Sources==
 
==Sources==
−
This guideline specifically excludes maps and census tables from consideration when establishing topic notability, because these sources often establish little except the existence of the subject. Still, they do contribute to the satisfaction of [[WP:V|the requirement of verifiability]].
+
This guideline specifically excludes maps and various tables from consideration when establishing topic notability, because these sources often establish little except the existence of the subject. Still, they do contribute to the satisfaction of [[WP:V|the requirement of verifiability]].
     
On the other hand, sources that describe the subject instead of simply mentioning it do establish notability.
 
On the other hand, sources that describe the subject instead of simply mentioning it do establish notability.

Many artificial geographical features may be mentioned in plenty of reliable sources, but they may not necessarily be notable. The inclusion of a man-made geographical feature on maps or in directories is insufficient to establish topic notability.
−
* '''Artificial geographical features''' that are officially assigned the status of ''[[cultural heritage]]'' or ''[[national heritage site|national heritage]]'', or of any other protected status on a national level and which [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] information beyond simple statistics are available, are presumed to be notable.
+
* '''Artificial geographical features''' that are officially assigned the status of ''[[cultural heritage]]'' or ''[[national heritage site|national heritage]]'', or of any other protected status on a national level and for which [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] information beyond simple statistics is available, are presumed to be notable.
 
* '''Buildings, including private residences and [[Real estate development|commercial developments]]''', may be notable as a result of their historic, social, economic, or architectural importance, but they require significant coverage by reliable, third-party sources to establish notability.
 
* '''Buildings, including private residences and [[Real estate development|commercial developments]]''', may be notable as a result of their historic, social, economic, or architectural importance, but they require significant coverage by reliable, third-party sources to establish notability.
 
* '''Artificial features related to [[infrastructure]]''' (for example, [[bridge]]s and [[dam]]s) can be notable under Wikipedia's [[WP:GNG|GNG]]. Where their notability is unclear, they generally redirect to more general articles or to a ''named natural feature'' that prompted their creation, e.g., to an article about the notable road it carries or the notable obstacle it spans.

Line 44: Line 44:  
==Roadways==
 
==Roadways==
 
{{Shortcut|WP:GEOROAD}}
 
{{Shortcut|WP:GEOROAD}}
  +
{{seealso|Wikipedia:Notability (highways)}}
 
International road networks (such as the [[International E-road network]]), [[Interstate Highway System|Interstate]], national, [[State highway|state]] and provincial highways are typically notable. # '''Populated, legally recognized places''' are typically presumed to be notable, even if their population is very low. * '''Populated, legally recognized places''' are typically presumed to be notable, even if their population is very low. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can remain notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. One exception is that [[census tract]]s are usually not considered notable.
  + −
# '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the GNG. Examples may include subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, informal regions of a state, unofficial neighborhoods, etc. – any of which could be considered notable on a case-by-case basis, given non-trivial coverage in multiple, independent reliable sources. If a Wikipedia article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the informal place should be included in the more general article on the legally recognized populated place or administrative subdivision that contains it.
+
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the GNG. If a Wikipedia article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the informal place should be included in the more general article on the legally recognized populated place or administrative subdivision that contains it.
⚫
# '''Disputed regions''' are generally considered case-by-case. Their notability for Wikipedia is independent of the validity of their claims. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
    + ⚫
# '''Named natural features''' are often notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands, etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is enough verifiable content for an encyclopedic article. For example, a river island with no information available except name and location should probably be described in an article on the river.

+

* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are typically considered notable, if any [[WP:TRIVIA|non-trivial]] [[WP:V|vefiriable]] data are available about them, even if their population is very low. +
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are typically considered notable, even if their population is very low. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can remain notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. One exception is that [[Census tract#United States|census tracts]] in the US are usually not considered notable.
     
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the GNG. Examples may include subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, informal regions of a state, unofficial neighborhoods, etc. – any of which could be considered notable on a case-by-case basis, given non-trivial coverage in multiple, independent reliable sources. If a Wikipedia article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the informal place should be included in the more general article on the legally-recognized populated place or administrative subdivision that contains it.

[[WP:IRS|Reliable sources]] that document and [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verify]] governmental recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are usually adequate to establish notability.
+
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are typically considered notable, even if their population is very low. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can remain notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. [[WP:IRS|Reliable sources]] that document and [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verify]] governmental recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are usually adequate to establish notability. One exception is that [[Census tract#United States|census tracts]] in the US are usually not considered notable.
     
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the GNG. Examples may include subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, informal regions of a state, unofficial neighborhoods, etc. – any of which could be considered notable on a case-by-case basis, given non-trivial coverage in multiple, independent reliable sources. If a Wikipedia article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the informal place should be included in the more general article on the legally-recognized populated place or administrative subdivision that contains it.

==No inherited notability==
 
==No inherited notability==
 
Geographical features must be notable on their own merits. They cannot [[WP:INHERIT|inherit]] the notability of [[Wikipedia:Notability (organizations and companies)|organizations]], [[Wikipedia:Notability (people)|people]], or [[Wikipedia:Notability (events)|events]].

This guideline ''does not'' apply to geographical features in [[fiction|fictional works]] or to the features of [[Wikipedia:Notability (astronomical objects)|celestial bodies]].

* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low or at zero. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can remain notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. +
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if their population is very low. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can remain notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. [[WP:IRS|Reliable sources]] that document and [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verify]] governmental recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are usually adequate to establish notability.
     
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the GNG. Examples may include subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, micronations, informal regions of a state, unofficial neighborhoods, etc. – any of which could be considered notable on a case-by-case basis, given non-trivial coverage in multiple, independent reliable sources. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the informal place should be included in the more general article on the legally-recognized populated place that contains it (if none, use the containing named natural feature).
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the GNG. Examples may include subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, micronations, informal regions of a state, unofficial neighborhoods, etc. – any of which could be considered notable on a case-by-case basis, given non-trivial coverage in multiple, independent reliable sources. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the informal place should be included in the more general article on the legally-recognized populated place that contains it (if none, use the containing named natural feature).

* '''Named natural features''' are often notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands, etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an encyclopedic article. * '''Disputed regions''' are generally considered case-by-case. Their notability for wikipedia is independent of the validity of their claims. +
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low or at zero. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can remain notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. Reliable sources that document and [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verify]] governmental recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are usually adequate to establish notability.
     
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the GNG. Examples may include subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, micronations, informal regions of a state, unofficial neighborhoods, etc. – any of which could be considered notable on a case-by-case basis, given non-trivial coverage in multiple, independent reliable sources. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the informal place should be included in the more general article on the legally-recognized populated place that contains it (if none, use the containing named natural feature).

* '''Named natural features''' are often notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands, etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an encyclopedic article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.

For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
     
* '''Disputed regions''' are generally considered case-by-case. Their notability for wikipedia is independent of the validity of their claims. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.

Line 13: Line 13:  
==Geographic regions, areas and places==
 
==Geographic regions, areas and places==
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low or at zero. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can remain notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. Reliable sources that document and [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verify]] governmental recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are usually adequate to establish notability.
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low or at zero. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can remain notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. Reliable sources that document and [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verify]] governmental recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are usually adequate to establish notability.
  +  
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case-by-case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a [[municipality]], but has no formal legal boundaries, can be deemed notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case-by-case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a [[municipality]], but has no formal legal boundaries, can be deemed notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
  +  
* '''Named natural features''' are often notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands, etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an encyclopedic article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
 
* '''Named natural features''' are often notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands, etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an encyclopedic article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
  +  
* '''Disputed regions''' are generally considered case-by-case. Their notability for wikipedia is independent of the validity of their claims. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
 
* '''Disputed regions''' are generally considered case-by-case. Their notability for wikipedia is independent of the validity of their claims. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
  +  
* '''Micronations'''{{spaced ndash}} Topic notability for micronations is usually based upon having received significant coverage in independent, [[WP:RS|reliable sources]], per Wikipedia's [[WP:GNG|General notability guideline]].

This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands, etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an encyclopedic article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
 
* '''Named natural features''' are often notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands, etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an encyclopedic article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
    −
* '''Disputed regions''' are considered case-by-case. Their notability for wikipedia is independent of the validity of their claims. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
+
* '''Disputed regions''' are generally considered case-by-case. Their notability for wikipedia is independent of the validity of their claims. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
     
* '''Micronations'''{{spaced ndash}} Topic notability for micronation articles is usually based upon having received significant coverage in independent, [[WP:RS|reliable sources]], per Wikipedia's [[WP:GNG|General Notability Guideline]].
 
* '''Micronations'''{{spaced ndash}} Topic notability for micronation articles is usually based upon having received significant coverage in independent, [[WP:RS|reliable sources]], per Wikipedia's [[WP:GNG|General Notability Guideline]].

This guideline ''does not'' apply to geographical features in [[fiction|fictional works]] or to the features of [[Wikipedia:Notability (astronomical objects)|celestial bodies]].

This guideline ''does not'' apply to geographical features in [[fiction|fictional works]] or to the features of [[Wikipedia:Notability (astronomical objects)|celestial bodies]].

Line 6: Line 6:  
}}
 
}}
    −
On Wikipedia, the [[Wikipedia:Notability|notability]] of some [[geographical feature]]s ([[Location (geography)|places]], objects, etc.) may be called into question. Per Wikipedia's [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|Five pillars]], the encyclopedia also functions as a [[gazetteer]]; therefore, geographical features meeting [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's General Notability Guideline]] are ''presumed'' (but not guaranteed) to be notable. This guideline summarizes the existing consensus for geographical [[WP:N|topic notability]] and provides guidance in establishing the notability of geographic features.
+
Per Wikipedia's [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|Five pillars]], the encyclopedia also functions as a [[gazetteer]]; therefore, geographical features meeting [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's General Notability Guideline]] are ''presumed'' (but not guaranteed) to be notable. On Wikipedia, the [[Wikipedia:Notability|notability]] of some [[geographical feature]]s ([[Location (geography)|places]], objects, etc.) may be called into question. This guideline summarizes the existing consensus for geographical [[WP:N|topic notability]] and provides guidance in establishing the notability of geographic features.

They require significant coverage by [[WP:Sources|reliable]], third-party sources to establish notability. * '''Artificial features related to [[infrastructure]]''' might be notable under Wikipedia's General Notability Guideline. Where their notability is unclear, they generally redirect to more general articles on the project or to a '''named natural feature''' that prompted their creation. Articles that meet notability guidelines typically qualify for a stand-alone article. Those that don't typically redirect to an article about the notable road it carries or the notable obstacle it spans.

Line 25: Line 25:  
Many artificial geographical features have plenty of verifiable information available, but they may not be notable. Those that satisfy [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's General Notability Guideline]] typically qualify for a separate, stand-alone article. Directory listing and personal blog entries do not establish topic notability. The inclusion of a man-made geographical feature on maps or in directories is not sufficient to establish topic notability.

Line 16: Line 16:  
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case-by-case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a [[municipality]], but has no formal legal boundaries, can be deemed notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case-by-case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a [[municipality]], but has no formal legal boundaries, can be deemed notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
    −

If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.

The inclusion of a man-made geographical feature on maps or in directories is not sufficient to establish topic notability.

Line 13: Line 13:  
==Geographic regions, areas and places==
 
==Geographic regions, areas and places==
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low or at zero. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can remain notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. Reliable sources that document and [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verify]] governmental recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are usually adequate to establish notability.
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low or at zero. Even [[Ghost town|abandoned]] places can remain notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses their entire history]]. Reliable sources that document and [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verify]] governmental recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are usually adequate to establish notability.
  +  
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case-by-case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a [[municipality]], but has no formal legal boundaries, can be deemed notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case-by-case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a [[municipality]], but has no formal legal boundaries, can be deemed notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
  +  
* '''Named natural features''' are often considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the natural geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
 
* '''Named natural features''' are often considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the natural geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
  +  
* '''Micronations''' are generally not inherently notable. The topic notability for micronation articles should be based upon having received significant coverage in independent, [[WP:RS|reliable sources]], per Wikipedia's [[WP:GNG|General Notability Guideline]].
 
* '''Micronations''' are generally not inherently notable. The topic notability for micronation articles should be based upon having received significant coverage in independent, [[WP:RS|reliable sources]], per Wikipedia's [[WP:GNG|General Notability Guideline]].
 
* '''Disputed regions''' are considered case-by-case. Their notability for wikipedia is independent of the validity of their claims. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.

If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.

Line 13: Line 13:  
==Geographic regions, areas and places==
 
==Geographic regions, areas and places==
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low or at zero. Even if a place is [[Ghost town|abandoned]], it remains notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses its entire history]]. Sources documenting government recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are adequate to establish notability provided they are [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]].
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low or at zero. Even if a place is [[Ghost town|abandoned]], it remains notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses its entire history]]. Sources documenting government recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are adequate to establish notability provided they are [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]].
  +  
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case-by-case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a [[municipality]], but has no formal legal boundaries, can be deemed notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.

−
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case-by-case. * '''Named natural features''' are often considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the natural geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.

[[Roadway]]s (highways, streets, etc.), whether named or not, are ''not'' inherently notable. Under [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's General Notability Guideline]], they must have received significant coverage in independent, [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] to be considered notable. Neither are [[WP:SIGCOV|trivial mentions]] of roadways in reports of [[Wikipedia:Notability (events)|notable events]], such as major disasters.

Line 16: Line 16:  
==Geographic regions, areas and places==
 
==Geographic regions, areas and places==
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. Even if the place is [[Ghost town|abandoned]], it remains notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses its entire history]]. Sources documenting government recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are adequate to establish notability provided they are [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]].
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. Even if the place is [[Ghost town|abandoned]], it remains notable, because [[WP:NTEMP|notability encompasses its entire history]]. Sources documenting government recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are adequate to establish notability provided they are [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]].
−
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case by case. This includes unofficial neighbourhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a [[municipality]], but has no formal legal boundaries, can be deemed notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
+
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case-by-case. This includes unofficial neighbourhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a [[municipality]], but has no formal legal boundaries, can be deemed notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
 
* '''Named natural features''' are often considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the natural geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.

* '''[[Micronation]]s''' are ''not'' inherently notable. Under [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's General Notability Guideline]], they must have received significant coverage in independent, [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] to be considered notable.

This includes unofficial neighbourhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a [[municipality]], but has no formal legal boundaries, can be deemed notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
 
* '''Named natural features''' are often considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the natural geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.

* '''[[Micronation]]s''' are not inherently notable. Under [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's General Notability Guideline]], they must have received significant coverage in independent, [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] to be considered notable.

On Wikipedia, the [[Wikipedia:Notability|notability]] of some [[geographical feature]]s ([[Location (geography)|places]], objects, etc.) may be called into question. Per Wikipedia's [[Wikipedia:Five pillars|Five pillars]], the encyclopedia also functions as a [[gazetteer]], and the purpose of this guideline is to summarize the existing consensus on geographical article inclusion and to provide general guidance in establishing the notability of a geographic feature. For the purpose of this guideline, a geographical feature is any reasonably permanent feature of the Earth, whether natural or artificial. The guideline ''does not'' apply to the features of [[Wikipedia:Notability (astronomical objects)|other celestial bodies]].
+

For the purpose of this guideline, a geographical feature is any reasonably permanent feature of the Earth, whether natural or artificial. The guideline ''does not'' apply to geographical features in fiction or to the features of [[Wikipedia:Notability (astronomical objects)|other celestial bodies]].

Line 17: Line 17:  
==Buildings and objects==
 
==Buildings and objects==
    −
There are quite a few artificial geographical features which have plenty of verifiable information available (e.g., in the form of construction plans or local coverage), but they may not be notable, being inherently [[Wikipedia:ROTM|run-of-the-mill]], ordinary objects. Those that satisfy [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's general notability guideline]] typically qualify for a separate, stand-alone article. The inclusion of an artificial geographic feature on maps or in directories is not sufficient to establish notability.
+
Many artificial geographical features have plenty of verifiable information available (e.g., in the form of construction plans or local coverage), but they may not be notable, being inherently [[Wikipedia:ROTM|run-of-the-mill]], ordinary objects. Those that satisfy [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's General Notability Guideline]] typically qualify for a separate, stand-alone article. The inclusion of an artificial geographic feature on maps or in directories is not sufficient to establish notability.
     
* '''Private residences''' are not generally notable. Articles ''can'' be created on historic buildings that a notable person has lived in, or that are notable for another reason, such as [[WP:Verifiability|verifiable]] recognition of the home as an architectural landmark.
 
* '''Private residences''' are not generally notable. Articles ''can'' be created on historic buildings that a notable person has lived in, or that are notable for another reason, such as [[WP:Verifiability|verifiable]] recognition of the home as an architectural landmark.
 
* Other '''buildings and commercial developments''' might be notable as a result of their historic, social, or architectural significance. They require significant coverage by [[WP:Sources|reliable]], third-party sources to establish notability. The sources should demonstrate [[WP:Verifiability|verifiable]] interest in the subject beyond its local area.
 
* Other '''buildings and commercial developments''' might be notable as a result of their historic, social, or architectural significance. They require significant coverage by [[WP:Sources|reliable]], third-party sources to establish notability. The sources should demonstrate [[WP:Verifiability|verifiable]] interest in the subject beyond its local area.
−
* '''Artificial features related to infrastructure''' should redirect to more general articles on the [[project]] or '''named natural feature''' that prompted their construction unless they have [[WP:Verifiability|verifiable]] [[WP:GNG|notability]] in their own right or no such article exists. For example, an article about a canal would be acceptable if the canal was a [[WP:GNG|notable]], stand-alone [[project]], but an article about an [[Wikipedia:ROTM|ordinary]] road bridge should redirect to an article about the notable road it carries or the notable obstacle it spans.
+
* '''Artificial features related to infrastructure''' might be notable under [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's General Notability Guideline]]. Where their notability is unclear, they should redirect to more general articles on the [[project]] or '''named natural feature''' that prompted their creation. For example, an article about a canal would be acceptable if the canal was a [[WP:GNG|notable]], stand-alone [[project]], but an article about an [[Wikipedia:ROTM|ordinary]] road bridge should redirect to an article about the notable road it carries or the notable obstacle it spans.

Line 11: Line 11:  
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. Even if the place is [[Ghost town|abandoned]], it still remains notable, because notability (i.e., potential interest) encompasses its entire history. Sources documenting government recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are adequate to establish notability provided they are [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]].
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. Even if the place is [[Ghost town|abandoned]], it still remains notable, because notability (i.e., potential interest) encompasses its entire history. Sources documenting government recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are adequate to establish notability provided they are [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]].
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case by case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case by case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
−
* '''Named natural features''' are often considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the natural geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is enough [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
+
* '''Named natural features''' are often considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the natural geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
 
* '''[[Micronations]]''' have not been considered as inherently notable, and independent sources should be presented to establish their notability.
 
* '''[[Micronations]]''' have not been considered as inherently notable, and independent sources should be presented to establish their notability.
 
* '''Disputed regions''' are considered case by case. The validity of the claims is irrelevant for wikipedia. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
 
* '''Disputed regions''' are considered case by case. The validity of the claims is irrelevant for wikipedia. Line 11: Line 11:  
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. Even if the place is [[Ghost town|abandoned]], it still remains notable, because notability (i.e., potential interest) encompasses its entire history. Sources documenting government recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are adequate to establish notability provided they are [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]].
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. Even if the place is [[Ghost town|abandoned]], it still remains notable, because notability (i.e., potential interest) encompasses its entire history. Sources documenting government recognition of a place, such as a national [[census]], are adequate to establish notability provided they are [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]].
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case by case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered case by case. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
−
* '''Named natural features''' are often considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the natural geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is enough [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the named geographic feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
+
* '''Named natural features''' are often considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the natural geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is enough [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
 
* '''[[Micronations]]''' have not been considered as inherently notable, and independent sources should be presented to establish their notability.
 
* '''[[Micronations]]''' have not been considered as inherently notable, and independent sources should be presented to establish their notability.
 
* '''Disputed regions''' are considered case by case. The validity of the claims is irrelevant for wikipedia. Sometimes it may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.

For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.

For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.

* '''Named geographic features''' are often considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is enough [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the named geographic feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.

There are quite a few artificial geographical features which have plenty of verifiable information available (e.g., in the form of constructin plans or local coverage), but they are unlikely to be notable, being inherently run-of-the-mill, ordinary objects. Of course, some of them may satisfy [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's general notability guideline]], but only a few of the kind listed in the examples below may secure a separate article:
  ⚫
* Nearly every house is listed in some directory somewhere, identifying the company that built it and the people who live in it. This does not make it notable. Additionally, there are privacy issues when it comes to writing about a personal residence. Articles ''can'' be created on historic houses that a notable person has lived in, or that are notable for another reason. Apartment complexes, housing developments, and trailer parks, even though there may be websites about each one, and even though they are often displayed on maps, are not notable on this basis.

==Particular cases==

* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. When notability is challenged, it can be helpful to reliably document that a place is legally recognized in some way. For example, the United States Census Bureau uses [[census-designated place]]s, and Statistics Canada uses [[designated place]]s as terms to classify populated areas.

* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
Line 15: Line 14:      
* '''Disputed regions''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. The validity of the claims is generally less important than the quality of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] available and the notability of the disputed region. It may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
 
* '''Disputed regions''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. The validity of the claims is generally less important than the quality of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] available and the notability of the disputed region. It may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.

* '''Named geographic features''' are usually considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is enough [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the named geographic feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.

On Wikipedia, the notability of some geographical places is sometimes called into question. Per Wikipedia's [[WP:5|Five pillars]], the encyclopedia also functions as a [[gazetteer]], and as such the purpose of this page is to define the existing consensus on geographical article inclusion and to provide general guidance to those wondering about the notability of a geographic area or region.
     
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. It is important though, when notability is challenged, to reliably document that a place is legally recognized in some way. Examples include government recognition of the place as a municipality or region, or recognition by a government agency such as the [[United States Census Bureau]] as a place (in this specific case, it would be called a [[census-designated place]]).
 
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. It is important though, when notability is challenged, to reliably document that a place is legally recognized in some way. Examples include government recognition of the place as a municipality or region, or recognition by a government agency such as the [[United States Census Bureau]] as a place (in this specific case, it would be called a [[census-designated place]]).

Line 8: Line 8:  
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
 
* '''Named geographic features''' are usually considered notable, provided information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for the geographic feature. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The number of known sources should be considered to ensure there is enough [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] content for an [[Wikipedia:encyclopedic|encyclopedic]] article. If an encyclopedic article cannot be developed using known sources, information on the named geographic feature should be included in a more general article on local geography. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.

* '''[[Micronations]]''' have not been considered as inherently notable, and sources should be presented to establish their notability.
 
* '''Disputed regions''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. The validity of the claims is generally less important than the quality of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] available and the notability of the disputed region. It may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.

Line 3: Line 3:  
On Wikipedia, the notability of some geographical places is sometimes called into question. The purpose of this page is to define the existing consensus on geographical article inclusion, to avoid wasting time on unnecessary AFDs, and to provide general guidance to those wondering about the notability of a given piece of geography.
 
On Wikipedia, the notability of some geographical places is sometimes called into question. The purpose of this page is to define the existing consensus on geographical article inclusion, to avoid wasting time on unnecessary AFDs, and to provide general guidance to those wondering about the notability of a given piece of geography.
    −
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. It is important though, when notability is challenged, to reliably document that a place is legally recognized in some way. Examples include government recognition of the place as a municipality or region, or recognition by a government agency such as the [[United States Census Bureau]] as a place (in this specific case, it would be called a [[census-designated place]]). AFDs of articles where no one disputes that the place legally exists are almost always closed early by overwhelming consensus to keep.
+
* '''Populated, legally-recognized places''' are, by a very large consensus, considered notable, even if the population is very low. It is important though, when notability is challenged, to reliably document that a place is legally recognized in some way. Examples include government recognition of the place as a municipality or region, or recognition by a government agency such as the [[United States Census Bureau]] as a place (in this specific case, it would be called a [[census-designated place]]). AFDs of articles where no one disputes that the place legally exists are [[WP:NPLACE|almost always closed]] early by overwhelming consensus to keep.
 
* '''Defunct legally-recognized places''' are considered notable.
 
* '''Defunct legally-recognized places''' are considered notable.
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
 
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.

This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. +
* '''Populated places without legal recognition''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. This includes unofficial neighborhoods, subdivisions, business parks, housing developments, "regions" of a state, etc. The lack of an official charter and legal boundaries and other documentation means that we will have to weigh the quality of non-official information on a place to determine notability. For example, a named subdivision that takes up part of a county, but has no formal legal boundaries, will be notable if evidence can be shown of substantial non-trivial information about that subdivision.
−
*'''Named geographic features''' are usually considered notable. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The amount of sources and notability of the place are still important, however. If little information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for a named geographic feature, there is probably not enough verifiable content for an article. Rather than deletion, these articles should be merged and redirected to a more general geographic article. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
+
* '''Named geographic features''' are usually considered notable. This includes mountains, lakes, streams, islands etc. The amount of sources and notability of the place are still important, however. If little information beyond statistics and coordinates is known to exist for a named geographic feature, there is probably not enough verifiable content for an article. Rather than deletion, these articles should be merged and redirected to a more general geographic article. For example, an article on a river island where there is no information available except the name and the location should probably redirect to the article on the river.
−
*'''[[Micronations]]''' are not considered inherently notable, and sources must be presented to establish their notability.
+
* '''[[Micronations]]''' are not considered inherently notable, and sources must be presented to establish their notability.
−
*'''Disputed regions''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. The validity of the claims is generally less important than the quality of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] available and the notability of the disputed region. It may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
+
* '''Disputed regions''' are considered on a case-by-case basis. The validity of the claims is generally less important than the quality of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] available and the notability of the disputed region. It may be more appropriate to merge these articles to ones on a broader conflict or political movement, or to merge articles on multiple disputed names for the same region into one article.
